Award.AwardTitle: Magneto-Optical Studies of Charge dissociation, Transport, and Collection in Organic Solar Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to investigate the critical parameters in controlling charge dissociation at donor-acceptor interfaces, charge transport in interpenetrating donor and acceptor networks, and charge collection at electrodes in organic solar cells. The approach is to use unique magneto-optical measurements: magnetic field effects of photocurrent and light-assisted dielectric response as effective tools to elucidate internal light-electricity conversion processes in organic bulk-heterojunction systems. The goal is to enhance the development of fundamental guidelines for material engineering and device design to develop highly efficient organic solar cells.
The intellectual merit includes the use of unique magneto-optical measurements for the investigation of internal photovoltaic processes towards the development of highly efficient organic solar cells. The unique magneto-optical measurements: magnetic field effects of photocurrent and light-assisted dielectric response can function as effective tools to ?visualize? the internal photovoltaic processes in the generation of photocurrent. The investigation of internal photovoltaic processes can elucidate the critical parameters to address critical issues involved in light-electricity conversion in controlling charge dissociation, transport, and collection processes in organic solar cells.
The broader impact includes the integration of research with education through curriculum development, class projects, minority and female student training, and outreach activities in the area of organic solar cells. On one hand, this project can impact the research and development of highly efficient organic solar cells. On the other hand, through the integration with education this project can enhance the preparation of high-quality working forces in renewable energy-engineering disciplines for economic development in our society.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, solar energy has been seen as one of the most promising renewable energy sources. Therefore, the research into solar cells and the development of the technology has gain more importance. Currently, expensive silicon-based solar cells are still considered the most widely used solar cell technology in the market mainly because of its relatively high efficiency. However, silicon solar cell has its limitations such as generally inflexible and fragile and the manufacturing procedure is time-consuming and costly. With new fabrication technologies and innovations and the demand for new alternative energy to meet global demands, the photovoltaic community has turned out a series of possibilities. One of these possibilities are organic solar cell which provides earth abundant and low energy production photovoltaic solution in solar technology. This class of solar cell has the advantage of being solution processable, lightweight, and flexible suitable for dual-purpose uses such as electronic skin and textiles, it is also environmentally a safe technology.

Although great effort has been made in materials processing and efficiency improvement in this new generation of solar cells, understanding of working mechanism to control the internal processes involve in light absorption, charge recombination, charge dissociation and transport mechanism are limited. This leaves much room for advancement of this technology. Therefore, understanding of internal processes and its developments are important and helpful in the optimization of solution-processed organic solar cells.

In a typical organic solar cell, as seen in Figure 1, sunlight is absorbed in the photoactive layers composed of donor and acceptor semiconducting organic materials to generate photocurrents. The donor material (D) donates electrons and mainly transports holes and the acceptor material (A) withdraws electrons and mainly transports electrons. As described in Figure 2, the general working mechanism of an organic solar cells follows absorption of light photons by the photoactive materials to create excitons, in which electrons are excited from the valence band into the conduction band (Light Absorption). Due to the concentration gradient, the excitons diffuse to the donor/acceptor interface (Exciton Diffusion) and separate into free holes (positive charge carriers) and electrons (negative charge carriers) (Charge Separation). A photovoltaic is generated when the holes and electrons move to the corresponding electrodes (Charge Extraction)

 The research supported by this award was designed to study internal photovoltaic processes in organic solar cells. Specifically, the project strategy is to develop the knowledge of sunlight conversion to electricity in organic solar cells and study the science behind it. Towards this goal, we implemented experimental designs by using magnetic field effects in combination with opto-electrical measurements. The objective of this experimental design is to elucidate the critical parameters in controlling internal photocurrent generation processes for materials processing and device engineering to develop highly efficient organic solar cells. We believe this project may enhance the key technology transfer of materials processing, device design and interface engineering in the field of organic solar cells.

The results of our experiments gave us a number of new insights into physics of organic solar cells. In particular, we have established two unique experimental tools: magnetic field effects of photocurrent and photoexcitation assisted dielectric response to experimentally “visualize” internal photovoltaic processes: charge dissociation, transport, and collection in organic solar cells.

We have also provided the fundamental information which is generally applicable to a broad range of organic nanocomposites and provide guidelines to control the morphology, function, and depth profile of the next generation of organic nanocomposites for solar cell technology. We discovered that dielectric interface can largely control the surface charge accumulation and therefore plays an important role in photovoltaic improvement. In addition, we have observed the dynamic coupling between the donor-acceptor interface and electrode interface in organic solar cells.

In general, this project may increase the societal understanding on the generation of renewable energies. It will benefit the solution development for future energy crisis by increasing energy conversion efficiencies and boosts economic development by developing cost-effective energy devices in our society.

Our unique experimental studies on internal photovoltaic processes can significantly contribute to other disciplines such as display technologies. Specifically, our experimental findings on charge dissociation, transport, and collection can provide new mechanism to control useful and non-useful light-emitting processes in flexible display organic light-emitting diodes.

This project mainly contributes to the development of highly skilled scientists and engineers in the field of opto-electronics especially photovoltaic technology.

This project mainly contributes to the development of highly skilled scientists and engineers in the field of opto-electronics especially photovoltaic technology.
